Award.AwardTitle: Structure/Function Correlations Over Binuclear Non-Heme Iron and Related Enzymes

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Organisms utilize binuclear non-heme iron enzymes to facilitate a wide range of chemical reactions using O2. As examples, humans need ribonucleotide reductase to generate DNA building blocks, and classes of bacteria use soluble methane monooxygenase to convert methane (a greenhouse gas) to methanol (a usable fuel). These enzymes have been targeted for the development of anti-cancer drugs and biofuel catalysts. Understanding their chemistry at a molecular level requires elucidating structural changes of the iron active core over the catalytic reaction; however, many of these are not accessible with traditional spectroscopic techniques. Thus, this project includes the development of new spectroscopic methodologies that utilize intense magnetic fields, circularly polarized light, and third-generation synchrotron radiation. Experimental data combined with quantum mechanical calculations will define reaction mechanisms of six enzymes and related models. The molecular level insight gained from this project will promote drug discovery and biotechnology. The methods developed have impact on many areas of science and are made available through numerous national and international collaborations, which are now expanding to undergrad-only U.S. institutions. This project also includes multiple outreach efforts, including participation of high school teachers/students in summer research in our labs and other K-12 programs. The PI has trained a large number of highly successful scientists and edits major scientific publications.

The binuclear non-heme enzymes form expanding classes that activate O2 for H-atom abstraction, desaturation, hydroxylation, and electrophilic attack, and reduce O2 to H2O and NO to N2O. The PI has been developing spectroscopic methodologies to probe their O2 activating reduced states (variable-temperature/variable-field magnetic circular dichroism, VTVH MCD,) and their oxygen intermediates (nuclear resonance vibrational spectroscopy, NRVS). The focus is now on: 1) understanding the mechanism of O2 activation by 1e- reduction (myoinositol oxygenase, the prototype that activates O2 as bound superoxide); 2) developing/using NRVS/MCD to define the nature and activation of peroxo-2FeIII intermediates; 3) extending Aim 2) to the high-valent intermediates Q in soluble methane monooxygenase and X in ribonucleotide reductase; 4) defining the mechanisms of O2 and NO reduction in flavin diiron proteins and other related classes; 5) continuing to develop/use VTVH MCD and other spectroscopies to understand structure/function correlations in new classes of these enzymes. These studies over a wide range of binuclear iron enzymes establish general principles utilized by multicenter enzymes for O2 activation and in directing catalysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported research into the superfamily of binuclear non-heme diiron (NH 2Fe) enzymes which incorporate oxygen into organic substrates. These enzymes share similar structural characteristics yet are able to perform unique chemistries on diverse substrates. The products after catalysis have been shown to have critical biological function and have implications in the search for alternative energy sources. The grant supported research into three representative NH 2Fe enzymes. The enzyme 4-aminobenzoate N-oxygenase (AurF) catalyzes the production of 4-nitrobenzoate in the biosynthesis of the antibiotic aureothin, which has been shown to have both antifungal and antitumor activity. CmlI, an enzyme similar to AurF in both structure and function, catalyzes the final biosynthetic step in the production of the antibiotic chloramphenicol. Soluble methane monooxygenase (sMMO) converts methane, a potent greenhouse gas, into the industrial liquid fuel methanol at ambient conditions. Methanol is regarded as one of the best alternative energy solutions to replace our fossil fuel economy and understanding the ambient conversion performed by biology can inform development of methane to methanol catalysts.

The goals of our research are threefold: 1) to relate the structure of these metalloenzymes to their function; 2) to understand the mechanisms by which these enzymes perform difficult chemical transformations; and 3) to develop methodologies complementary to these goals. These methodologies include a range of spectroscopic techniques, which we couple to density functional theory (DFT) to obtain foundational insight. Graduate students in this lab are trained to be experts in biophysics, computational methods and metalloprotein biochemistry, and we share our expertise through strong domestic and international collaborations. Outside of our scientific endeavors, members of the lab engage in a volunteer program which aims to inspire future generations of scientists by working with high school teachers to bring the materials for and incorporate modern experiments into chemistry classrooms. These outreach efforts focus on high schools that serve primarily under-represented and low-income students. 

With regards to our first scientific goal, we have made great strides in correlating the unique structures of NH 2Fe enzymes to their functions. We have used spectroscopy to elucidate the substrate reactive oxygen intermediate in AurF and coupled these experimental data with a computational study to understand how aromatic substrates are oxidized by binuclear iron enzymes. We correlated our findings on AurF to enzymes in the superfamily of mononuclear non-heme (NH Fe) enzymes. Our comparative analysis defined the importance of binuclear versus mononuclear iron active sites in enabling chemistry on the peroxide level, leading to a direct structure/function relationship in these classes of enzymes. Finally, we are extending our findings on Aurf to CmlI to obtain a broad understanding of peroxide-level oxygen intermediates in NH 2Fe enzymes.

We have also made progress into understanding the mechanisms by which NH 2Fe enzymes oxygenate inert substrates. The conversion of methane to methanol by sMMO represents one of the most difficult chemical reactions performed by iron enzymes. There is a significant debate as to the oxygen intermediate responsible for this reaction and ultimately the reaction mechanism. We have made extensive spectroscopic measurements of the methane-reactive intermediate over the course of this grant and have designed a spectroscopic methodology to determine its structure. Our work on sMMO will define this intermediate and determine key structural features that activate sMMO for reaction with inert organic compounds.

These studies were implemented using a combined spectroscopic/computational methodology that has been developed in our lab over the course of this NSF MCB funding. To understand the mechanisms of iron enzymes, we study their oxygen activated intermediates using magnetic circular dichroism (MCD) and nuclear resonance vibrational spectroscopy (NRVS). We first calibrate our study by performing MCD/NRVS on a library of well-documented model complexes. DFT calculations of these models provide the correct computational methodology to apply to the enzyme systems. We then collect spectroscopic data on the enzyme intermediates to determine their geometric and electronic structure, and hence understand their unique reactivity. Simulations of these data with DFT calculations then define the reaction mechanism, yielding fundamental insight into NH 2Fe enzyme chemistry.

The superfamily of NH 2Fe enzymes are essential in disciplines involving human health, catalysis, and bioremediation. Understanding the geometric and electronic structures of these enzymes and their oxygen-activated intermediates is crucial for technological advancement. The outcomes of our research have led to major insights into NH 2Fe chemistry, as well as methods development for continued research.


Last Modified: 05/27/2019
Modified by: Edward I Solomon
